title: ‘Public land, public vote’: Lake Worth Beach residents protest downtown development plan
description: The Weiner Museum of Decorative Arts plan consists of a four-story museum and commercial space on Lake Avenue. A group of residents oppose it.
content:
LAKE WORTH BEACH — More than 70 residents stood outside Lake Worth Beach City Hall before the scheduled Aug. 5 commission meeting, protesting against the Weiner Museum of Decorative Arts, a $60 million mixed-use downtown development project.

Protestors, many wearing red, held signs reading “Stop WMODA” and chanted “Public land, public vote!” earning car honks from drivers along South Dixie Highway.

Despite the pushback, city officials didn’t change course. Four of five commissioners voted to approve this iteration of the project master plan. Commissioner Christopher McVoy, who agreed with some protestors’ comments, was not present for the vote.

This is not the city’s final approval for WMODA. Officials will discuss the project once more before making an official decision, though the timing is unclear.

WMODA is projected to cost $60 million in total, with the city contributing an estimated $19 million.

Residents are concerned the city is putting a large sum of public taxpayer dollars toward a project proposed by a private developer.

“At the heart of most of it, the thing I think a lot of people disagree on is: it's too much money,” said Kim Stokes, a former city commissioner and a leader of the advocacy group Lake Worth 4 All.

The project will consist of a four-story museum and commercial space on Lake Avenue featuring 15,000 pieces of glass sculptures and ceramic artwork, a cafe, bookstore, classrooms and an exhibit by Dale Chihuly, a famous artist known for his large glass-blown pieces.

The project will also include a five-story, 110-apartment complex and an attached underground residential parking garage with 117 spaces. The city agreed to build an additional three-story, 270-space parking garage on K Street and split the funding with WMODA. This second garage will cost the city $7.5 million.

Lake Worth Beach values WMODA’s designated 1.7-acre property at about $3.3 million. However, the plan includes making some sacrifices, such as demolishing one historical building and relocating three others to Community Development Agency-approved sites.

“The project obliterates all the qualities of the (Old Town) historic district,” said Richard Stowe, who moved to Lake Worth Beach in 2012 and formerly served on the Tree and Landscape Board.

United Management, doing business as Sunshine Lake Worth Development, first proposed the project at an October 2024 workshop meeting. About 40 people showed up in support, wearing pro-WMODA shirts and flashing supportive signs. Now, the tone has shifted.

Just south of Lake Worth Beach, Boca Raton is also considering a similarly controversial mixed-use development plan.

Boca residents formed a group called “Save Boca” that protested outside the City Council chamber in July, circulating a petition and filling over 80 seats.

Lake Worth 4 All’s protest on Aug. 5 demanded the same thing of its city leaders: to put public-private issues on a ballot. During the commission meeting, protestors made an uproar over WMODA’s overall cost but targeted two key elements in particular: parking and affordable housing.

To meet the city’s parking requirement, WMODA’s plan would eliminate roughly 65 spaces. An informational pamphlet distributed by protestors claims the project would credit 66 public downtown spaces toward its total and treat 156 bike racks as the equivalent of 24 spaces, although the city has not confirmed these figures.

A group of eight residents circulated a petition against these parking plans and the introduction of paid parking downtown. One resident, Susan Guyaux, told the council they gathered 872 signatures within a 10-day period.

Would affordable housing be offered in the Lake Worth Beach development?

Lake Worth Beach citizens are also concerned about the small amount of affordable housing WMODA plans to offer.

The apartment complex is slated to have eight “Affordable Artists’ Lofts” reserved for households earning between roughly $85,600 and $128,500 annually. The remaining 102 units will sell at the local market rate, which sits at an average of $2,300 per month, according to data from real estate and rental listing websites such as Zillow and Apartments.com.

Tyler Chapman, founder of the nonprofit independent news blog The Lake Worthian, said he doesn't see any low-income benefit.

“Workforce housing, I think, is a cover for just gentrifying. It's not a truly helpful thing for them to do,” Chapman said in an interview. Chapman and others said the public subsidies put into workforce housing often only benefit higher-income buyers.

Commissioner Mimi May acknowledged that there is a need for more low-income housing, but also noted that those who can afford the current market rate are looking for more activities downtown, making that one reason WMODA makes sense for Lake Worth Beach.

LAKE WORTH BEACH NEWS: From West Palm Beach down to Lantana here are the top 22 places for waterfront dining

LAKE WORTH BEACH NEWS: State officials to meet with Palm Springs about bicycle lane barriers on Lake Worth Road

LAKE WORTH BEACH NEWS: Why Lake Worth Beach's Cam Smith is surging in AL Rookie of the Year race

Since 2011, Vice Mayor Sarah Malega confirmed, the city has established over 1,200 affordable residences, including workforce and deed-restricted units.

“Lake Worth Beach has more affordable and workforce housing being built than anywhere,” said William Waters, the city’s community sustainability director.

Those who attended the protest and the city commission meeting said they wanted their voices to be heard and for their fellow residents to stay informed.

Chapman wrote a piece about the project and other matters ahead of the Aug. 5 meeting, and both The Lake Worthian and Lake Worth 4 All have active websites and social media pages updating the public on city decisions.

“There’s a lot of issues in the city, (including) homelessness, addiction, crime … and we really want to be able to just have those community conversations and bring more awareness and more conversations,” Stokes said. “People need to know what’s going on.”

This article originally appeared on Palm Beach Post: Lake Worth Beach's $60 million WMODA project gets pushback
summary: Over 70 residents protested against the Weiner Museum of Decorative Arts (WMODA), a $60 million mixed-use downtown development project in Lake Worth Beach, Florida. The demonstrators held signs reading "Stop WMODA" and chanted "Public land, public vote!" despite the pushback. Despite this, four of five commissioners voted to approve this version of the project master plan. The project is expected to cost $60m, with the city contributing an estimated $19m. Concerns have been raised about the use of public taxpayer dollars for the project, which includes a four-story museum and commercial space featuring 15,000 pieces of glass sculptures and ceramic artwork. An additional three-story, 270-space parking garage on K Street will cost the city $7.5m.
shortSummary: Lake Worth Beach residents protested against the $60 million WMODA development, citing inadequate parking and affordable housing, and called for a public vote to protect public land.

scraped_sources.text:
‘Public land, public vote’: Lake Worth Beach residents protest downtown development plan
The Weiner Museum of Decorative Arts (WMODA) plan is a four-story museum, an apartment complex, parking garage and commercial space on Lake Avenue. Residents say the financials are bad for the city.
LAKE WORTH BEACH — More than 70 residents stood outside Lake Worth Beach City Hall before the scheduled Aug. 5 commission meeting, protesting against the Weiner Museum of Decorative Arts, a $60 million mixed-use downtown development project.
Protestors, many wearing red, held signs reading “Stop WMODA” and chanted “Public land, public vote!” earning car honks from drivers along South Dixie Highway.
Despite the pushback, city officials didn’t change course. Four of five commissioners voted to approve this iteration of the project master plan. Commissioner Christopher McVoy, who agreed with some protestors’ comments, was not present for the vote.
This is not the city’s final approval for WMODA. Officials will discuss the project once more before making an official decision, though the timing is unclear.
WMODA is projected to cost $60 million in total, with the city contributing an estimated $19 million.
Residents are concerned the city is putting a large sum of public taxpayer dollars toward a project proposed by a private developer.
“At the heart of most of it, the thing I think a lot of people disagree on is: it's too much money,” said Kim Stokes, a former city commissioner and a leader of the advocacy group Lake Worth 4 All.
The project will consist of a four-story museum and commercial space on Lake Avenue featuring 15,000 pieces of glass sculptures and ceramic artwork, a cafe, bookstore, classrooms and an exhibit by Dale Chihuly, a famous artist known for his large glass-blown pieces.
The project will also include a five-story, 110-apartment complex and an attached underground residential parking garage with 117 spaces. The city agreed to build an additional three-story, 270-space parking garage on K Street and split the funding with WMODA. This second garage will cost the city $7.5 million.
Lake Worth Beach values WMODA’s designated 1.7-acre property at about $3.3 million. However, the plan includes making some sacrifices, such as demolishing one historical building and relocating three others to Community Development Agency-approved sites.
“The project obliterates all the qualities of the (Old Town) historic district,” said Richard Stowe, who moved to Lake Worth Beach in 2012 and formerly served on the Tree and Landscape Board.
United Management, doing business as Sunshine Lake Worth Development, first proposed the project at an October 2024 workshop meeting. About 40 people showed up in support, wearing pro-WMODA shirts and flashing supportive signs. Now, the tone has shifted.
Just south of Lake Worth Beach, Boca Raton is also considering a similarly controversial mixed-use development plan.
Boca residents formed a group called “Save Boca” that protested outside the City Council chamber in July, circulating a petition and filling over 80 seats.
Lake Worth 4 All’s protest on Aug. 5 demanded the same thing of its city leaders: to put public-private issues on a ballot. During the commission meeting, protestors made an uproar over WMODA’s overall cost but targeted two key elements in particular: parking and affordable housing.
To meet the city’s parking requirement, WMODA’s plan would eliminate roughly 65 spaces. An informational pamphlet distributed by protestors claims the project would credit 66 public downtown spaces toward its total and treat 156 bike racks as the equivalent of 24 spaces, although the city has not confirmed these figures.
A group of eight residents circulated a petition against these parking plans and the introduction of paid parking downtown. One resident, Susan Guyaux, told the council they gathered 872 signatures within a 10-day period.
Would affordable housing be offered in the Lake Worth Beach development?
Lake Worth Beach citizens are also concerned about the small amount of affordable housing WMODA plans to offer.
The apartment complex is slated to have eight “Affordable Artists’ Lofts” reserved for households earning between roughly $85,600 and $128,500 annually. The remaining 102 units will sell at the local market rate, which sits at an average of $2,300 per month, according to data from real estate and rental listing websites such as Zillow and Apartments.com.
Tyler Chapman, founder of the nonprofit independent news blog The Lake Worthian, said he doesn't see any low-income benefit.
“Workforce housing, I think, is a cover for just gentrifying. It's not a truly helpful thing for them to do,” Chapman said in an interview. Chapman and others said the public subsidies put into workforce housing often only benefit higher-income buyers.
Commissioner Mimi May acknowledged that there is a need for more low-income housing, but also noted that those who can afford the current market rate are looking for more activities downtown, making that one reason WMODA makes sense for Lake Worth Beach.
Since 2011, Vice Mayor Sarah Malega confirmed, the city has established over 1,200 affordable residences, including workforce and deed-restricted units.
“Lake Worth Beach has more affordable and workforce housing being built than anywhere,” said William Waters, the city’s community sustainability director.
Those who attended the protest and the city commission meeting said they wanted their voices to be heard and for their fellow residents to stay informed.
Chapman wrote a piece about the project and other matters ahead of the Aug. 5 meeting, and both The Lake Worthian and Lake Worth 4 All have active websites and social media pages updating the public on city decisions.
“There’s a lot of issues in the city, (including) homelessness, addiction, crime … and we really want to be able to just have those community conversations and bring more awareness and more conversations,” Stokes said. “People need to know what’s going on.”

'Save Boca' group vents at City Hall; city says 'misinformation' has been circulating
Boca Raton residents have been begging city leaders to halt their government campus redevelopment plan, with not much response. They are finally fed up.
- Boca Raton residents protested a recently approved redevelopment plan at a city council meeting.
- The plan includes a new city hall, residential building, park, and other amenities on a 30-acre lot.
- Residents formed a group called Save Boca and are circulating petitions to require voter approval for similar projects.
- City officials maintain the project has been discussed extensively, but residents claim misinformation and lack of accessible communication.
- The redevelopment plan includes relocating recreational facilities, which has caused further pushback from residents.
BOCA RATON — Claiming their voices have not been heard by city leaders, Boca Raton residents filled all 80 or so seats, lined the walls and even sat outside City Hall chambers July 15 to express frustration, anger and exasperation at the city’s recently approved Government Campus Redevelopment plan.
The plan, in which the city is partnering with development groups Terra & Frisbie, would transform the landscape of a 30-acre lot that includes Memorial Park near Palmetto Park Road and the Brightline Station in downtown Boca Raton with a mixed-use project to replace aging buildings and add a new City Hall, residential building, park, community center, office space, retail and a 150-room hotel.
The city council entered into a non-binding interim agreement with the developer March 18. A final approval has not been reached.
Since then, residents have been persistent in begging the council to drop the plan and have even mounted a grassroots group called Save Boca that has circulated two petitions aimed at halting the downtown redevelopment plan. One petition would amend a city ordinance; the other, the City Charter. Both would require the city to get voter approval before selling or leasing any city-owned land larger than half an acre.
Already, the city charter petition has garnered more than 1,000 signatures, according to group leader and local Realtor Jon Pearlman. They need roughly 3,600 signatures to put the issue on a ballot.
➤ Access The Palm Beach Post on the go with the app: Our app offers a personalized experience to your liking. Download our app to personalize your news alerts, swipe and scroll through stories faster, and bookmark them to save and read later.
Many residents voiced their indignation over the city’s use of public tax dollars to fund a partnership with a private developer on a large sum of land — without a public vote.
“We are partners,” said James Henry, a Boca Raton resident of 42 years. “And the only way we are going to be able to negotiate something with all the good work going on here is to allow that partnership to flourish.”
Part of Save Boca’s efforts went toward urging as many people as possible to be present at the July 15 city council meeting. Pearlman estimates that about 100 residents showed up, and of that, 33 people spoke out.
Among those was local developer Pedro Voyer, who said the communication on the project leading up to the approval was minimal.
“I think that communication about these topics has been badly managed because it’s been very, I will say, electronic,” Voyer said. “But not in paper for all the generations of people that live in East Boca.”
Boca Raton officials disagreed.
Mayor Scott Singer said the city has discussed the redevelopment plan at 27 meetings and more than 100 communications have been sent out to city residents providing information on the state of the project.
The city said the project has been discussed at 25-plus workshop and council meetings and has a website with information, updates a timeline and project documents. The city emphasized it has held four open houses, sent 40-plus social media posts, eight text alerts and 22 email newsletters for residents.
Between comments, Singer noted repeatedly that a large amount of "misinformation" has been spread to residents and reminded attendees that the plan has already been approved.
“I get that we may disagree about some of the things and whether this is worthwhile, but I think everyone would do well to actually look at the plans before more misinformation gets out there,” Singer said.
Many residents, however, said not all communications have been accessible and many have only found out about the project through the new “Save Boca” movement.
“I sat here with nothing prepared, but having listened to the comments back and forth, my concern is that there needs to be some mutual respect for our residents,” Boca Raton resident Lori Colbert told the council. “You seem to think that we don’t read, that we don’t understand what’s going on. … Well, perhaps the misinformation is because the information you’ve provided … is a little bit confusing to people.”
City promises new recreational facilities
A big reason for the recent swell of pushback has come from skateboard and tennis enthusiasts opposing the loss of important recreational facilities.
The development plan, Singer said, does call for the city to relocate some of the recreational amenities elsewhere.
In fact, the city announced an agreement with the Greater Boca Raton Beach and Park District for the development of a softball field complex at Sugar Sand Park. Upon completion, the fields will be managed and run by the Park District.
The new, $12 million upgraded softball complex will replace and enhance the current single field on the Government Campus. The new complex will be next to the existing baseball facility and include four softball fields, batting cages, shade structures, concessions, restrooms and parking.
At previous meetings, others have cited issues with traffic, distance to new facilities and the use of public tax dollars.

'Chance of a lifetime': Lake Worth Beach rolls out $60M downtown museum/apartment plan
LAKE WORTH BEACH — Lake Worth Beach took a big step toward a plan that would have the city donate downtown property for a developer to build a $60 million mixed-use museum/apartment complex.
“It’s the chance of a lifetime. If we don’t do this, we’re going back to having just commercial and residential development in our downtown,” said Community Development Agency member Drew Bartlett at the October 7 workshop to consider the proposal from Wiener Museum of Decorative Arts (WMODA).
About 40 people, many with pro-project T-shirts and signs, attended the workshop at the Casino Building and Beach Complex.
The seven-member CDA voted the next day 6-1 to recommend approval. Member Daniel Morgan voted no.
Thumbs up and thumbs down came from several residents at the two-and-a-half-hour meeting.
“We’ve heard this before with the Gulfstream Hotel. Downtown development will bring tax revenue and bring jobs. Why haven’t we met that promise?” Lake Worth Beach resident David Simms said.
Graham MacLeod countered that long-needed additional downtown parking will result.
“The Lake Worth Playhouse, Bamboo Room and other downtown businesses lose customers due to lack of parking,” said MacLeod, who also lives in Lake Worth Beach.
The next step is the Tuesday, Oct. 15 preliminary city commission vote. The final vote by the commission is scheduled for Tuesday, Oct. 29.
What are the details for the public/private partnership downtown plan?
The core of the plan calls for the city to donate 1.7 acres to the Wiener Museum’s development company, United Management. The property, valued by the city at about $3.3 million, is at the southwest corner of Lake Avenue and South M Street.
Other details include:
- United Management would build a four-story museum to display WMODA’s 15,000 pieces of decorative glass and ceramic artwork. A cafe, bookstore, classrooms and an exhibit by Dale Chihuly are planned.
- United Management would build a 110-unit apartment complex to include eight affordable housing lofts for artists. A three-story parking garage would have about 280 spaces. The garage would be owned and operated by the city, and public parking would be allowed.
- An “active alley,” a pedestrian-only landscaped walkway between the museum and parking garage, would be built.
- Four historic buildings now on the property would be moved to nearby CDA-owned property.
Such public/private partnerships are not new.
A plan to give Vanderbilt University two acres of land near downtown West Palm Beach valued at about $13 million was approved last month by the West Palm Beach city commission.
Nashville-based Vanderbilt would use the land off Tamarind Avenue to help build a $500 million, 300,000-square-foot graduate school campus. Palm Beach County must agree to donate another five acres of land it owns for the plan to be finalized.
Vanderbilt officials say the graduate school will generate $7.1 billion in economic activity over the next 25 years. Thousands of jobs, from teaching to construction to food services, will be created, they say.
LAKE WORTH BEACH NEWS: Why the new Sixth Avenue South bridge still hasn't opened, more than year after work began
The WMODA project will bring about $14 million in tax revenue to Lake Worth Beach in the next decade, museum officials say.
CDA member Morgan questioned how affordable housing, parking and historical preservation are being addressed.
“This is not a proper use of taxpayer funds,” Morgan said at the CDA workshop.
How would the mixed-use development generate money for Lake Worth Beach?
WMODA officials estimate about 50,000 people will visit the museum annually.
By comparison, Loggerhead Marinelife Center in Juno Beach drew about 310,000 visitors last year. The Morikami Museum and Japanese Gardens annually draws about 200,000 visitors. The Henry Morrison Flagler Museum in Palm Beach draws about 100,000 visitors annually, according to local officials.
Drawing more visitors — and their spending — to Lake Worth Beach would be a direct result of WMODA, said resident Ricardo Hernandez.
“The museum will elevate Lake Worth Beach and stimulate the local economy,” said Hernandez, a Realtor.
LAKE WORTH BEACH NEWS: Gulfstream Hotel finally changes hands. What's next for this historic Lake Worth Beach property?
A non-profit, 501(c)3 organization, WMODA now stores its artwork in Hollywood, Fla. while looking for a permanent location.
Arthur Wiener, WMODA founder, wants to “leave a legacy” by establishing the museum.
Wiener, 80, said he had family members killed in the Nazi Holocaust and has lost family members in the Middle East conflict that started a year ago on Oct. 7.
“This country has been very good to my family. I want this museum to become an institution in Lake Worth Beach,” Wiener said Monday night.
What's next for the plan?
- Tuesday, Oct. 15, 6 p.m., Lake Worth Beach City Hall, 7 N. Dixie Highway, Lake Worth Beach: City Commission to consider preliminary approval of the WMODA agreement. The meeting is open to the public.
- Tuesday, Oct. 29, 5 p.m., Lake Worth Beach City Hall: Lake Worth Beach City Commission to consider final approval of the WMODA agreement. The meeting is open to the public.

Why Lake Worth Beach's Cam Smith is surging in AL Rookie of the Year race
A Lake Worth Beach native enters July among the top betting favorites for the American League Rookie of the Year.
Cam Smith, a Palm Beach Central graduate, is surging over the summer with a batting average trending toward .300 and multi-hit outings in six of his last seven games.
Smith touts a .291 batting average, 7 home runs and 38 RBI and 2.5 Wins Above Replacement (WAR) entering the Fourth of July holiday. The rookie has improved his average dramatically from a .207 mark two months prior.
The offensive improvement has coincided with a rise in Smith's odds in the AL Rookie of the Year race.
According to BetMGM, Smith now holds second-best odds (+160) for Rookie of the Year behind only Jacob Wilson (-150) of the Oakland Athletics.
No player among the top eight contenders has improved his odds more than Smith, who opened the year +8000 to win AL Rookie of the Year.
MLB Rookie of the Year odds
Here's a look at the latest AL Rookie of the Year odds from BetMGM as of July 4:
- Player, Team: (Current Odds) / (Starting Odds)
- Jacob Wilson, Athletics: (-160) / (+700)
- Cam Smith, Astros: (+160) / (+8000)
- Nick Kurtz, Athletics: (+450) / (+8000)
- Roman Anthony, Red Sox: (+2800) / (+700)
- Jac Caglianone, Royals: (+3500) / (+3000)
Jacob Wilson stats
Wilson the sixth-overall pick in the 2023 MLB Draft out of Grand Canyon, remains the clear favorite for the award thanks to his gaudy production.
The rookie shortstop enters the Fourth of July holiday with a .339 batting average, nine home runs and 40 RBI with a 2.1 WAR.
Wilson was recently scratched from the Athletics' lineup due to right hamstring soreness in a move made "out of caution" according to Oakland manager Mark Kotsay.
Roman Anthony remains contender
West Palm Beach native Roman Anthony, who entered the year as the MLB's No. 1 prospect, remains among the Rookie of the Year favorites despite a slow start.
Anthony enters the Fourth of July holiday batting .200 with a home run, seven RBI and 0.3 WAR.
Unlike Smith, who made the Astros' opening day roster and has played with Houston since March, Anthony made his debut with the Red Sox on June 6.
Eric J. Wallace is deputy sports editor for The Palm Beach Post. He can be reached at ejwallace@gannett.com.

'Save Boca' group vents at City Hall; city says 'misinformation' has been circulating
Boca Raton residents have been begging city leaders to halt their government campus redevelopment plan, with not much response. They are finally fed up.
- Boca Raton residents protested a recently approved redevelopment plan at a city council meeting.

Many residents voiced their indignation over the city’s use of public tax dollars to fund a partnership with a private developer on a large sum of land — without a public vote.
“We are partners,” said James Henry, a Boca Raton resident of 42 years. “And the only way we are going to be able to negotiate something with all the good work going on here is to allow that partnership to flourish.”

Among those was local developer Pedro Voyer, who said the communication on the project leading up to the approval was minimal.
“I think that communication about these topics has been badly managed because it’s been very, I will say, electronic,” Voyer said. “But not in paper for all the generations of people that live in East Boca.”
Boca Raton officials disagreed.
Mayor Scott Singer said the city has discussed the redevelopment plan at 27 meetings and more than 100 communications have been sent out to city residents providing information on the state of the project.
The city said the project has been discussed at 25-plus workshop and council meetings and has a website with information, updates a timeline and project documents. The city emphasized it has held four open houses, sent 40-plus social media posts, eight text alerts and 22 email newsletters for residents.
Between comments, Singer noted repeatedly that a large amount of "misinformation" has been spread to residents and reminded attendees that the plan has already been approved.

“I sat here with nothing prepared, but having listened to the comments back and forth, my concern is that there needs to be some mutual respect for our residents,” Boca Raton resident Lori Colbert told the council. “You seem to think that we don’t read, that we don’t understand what’s going on. … Well, perhaps the misinformation is because the information you’ve provided … is a little bit confusing to people.”
City promises new recreational facilities
A big reason for the recent swell of pushback has come from skateboard and tennis enthusiasts opposing the loss of important recreational facilities.
The development plan, Singer said, does call for the city to relocate some of the recreational amenities elsewhere.
In fact, the city announced an agreement with the Greater Boca Raton Beach and Park District for the development of a softball field complex at Sugar Sand Park. Upon completion, the fields will be managed and run by the Park District.
The new, $12 million upgraded softball complex will replace and enhance the current single field on the Government Campus. The new complex will be next to the existing baseball facility and include four softball fields, batting cages, shade structures, concessions, restrooms and parking.
At previous meetings, others have cited issues with traffic, distance to new facilities and the use of public tax dollars.

State officials to meet with Palm Springs about bicycle lane barriers on Lake Worth Road
- Vehicle crashes into Lake Worth Road's bicycle lane barriers have decreased since the addition of plastic poles.
- Florida Department of Transportation (FDOT) will meet with Palm Springs officials to discuss further safety measures.
- FDOT maintains that drivers need to adjust to the new barriers, while local officials advocate for shorter barriers.
PALM SPRINGS — Fewer vehicles seem to be crashing into Lake Worth Road's new bicycle lane barriers ever since plastic white poles were installed on them, but they're not enough, local officials say, so they will beseech state transportation officials in July to do more examination.
Officials from the Florida Department of Transportation will meet July 21 with Palm Springs officials to discuss what more can be done to further reduce the number of collisions, which have spiked since the unveiling of concrete buffers in May on the road, which runs through the village. Crashes have declined since mid-June after FDOT installed white plastic poles and reflective pavement markers on the barriers but remain higher than before the road project.
Is installation of white poles enough?
Crashes have become less common since then, said Flora Hernandez, co-owner of a U-Haul rental on Lake Worth Road. When the bike lane buffers were first unveiled, she saw multiple crashes daily, she said. The last time she saw a crash was the weekend of the Fourth of July, she said July 9.
The white poles and reflectors are meant to keep drivers alert to the curb-like bike lane barriers. But still, black marks on the poles show evidence that drivers are still bumping into the barriers, said Florida state House Rep. Debra Tendrich, D-Lake Clarke Shores, who represents the legislative district covering Palm Springs and who has been working with state and local officials to help solve this issue.
FDOT "is expediting this," Tendrich said. "It's happening in weeks, not years like it took to put them in."
When FDOT staff visited Lake Worth Road on June 23, they told Palm Springs officials that drivers need to get used to the new bike lane barriers, Assistant Village Manager Kimberly Glas-Castro said. That was also what they told local officials in May, Glas-Castro has said.
FDOT is monitoring how effective its poles and reflectors are at reducing crashes, spokesman Guillermo Canedo said. Data collected by FDOT and local police are expected to be presented at the July 21 meeting. Palm Springs officials maintain that the barriers should be shorter, like the ones on Sansburys Way north of Belvedere Road, Glas-Castro said.
FDOT in November 2022 approved the installation of bike lane barriers as part of a $14 million project on Lake Worth Road to upgrade crosswalk pedestrian signal systems, replace or add road signs, add sidewalk curb ramps where there were none to meet federal disability standards and repair pipes and water mains underground.
The department owns and maintains Lake Worth Road. The 1.8-mile road's new design aims to improve safety and comfort for everyone, whether they walk, bike, drive or ride any of the road's five public bus routes, the Palm Beach Transportation Planning Agency has said. That federally mandated agency helps shepherd money through federal and state governments to help pay for local road projects.
Still, even with the barriers, poles and reflectors, bike riders rarely pedal in the lanes, opting instead for the newly widened 10- to 12-foot sidewalks.
“We have to protect bicyclists, but we also want to protect cars," Tendrich said. "We have to find a balance.”
Chris Persaud covers transportation in Palm Beach County for The Palm Beach Post. Email news tips and ideas to cpersaud@pbpost.com.

From West Palm Beach down to Lantana here are the top 22 places for waterfront dining
- Palm Beach County offers a variety of waterfront dining experiences.
- Restaurants provide views of the Intracoastal Waterway, Atlantic Ocean, and area lakes.
- Menus range from casual fare to upscale dining options.
- Many restaurants offer outdoor seating to enjoy the scenery.
Whether you're a lifelong resident or even if you've moved here in the past few years, you know that the dining scene in Palm Beach County is hopping.
You probably also know that there are a few restaurants, via their natural environment, that truly set themselves apart. That's right: waterfront dining.
When it comes to ambiance it's tough to beat gazing out over the beautiful Intracoastal Waterway, sitting alongside a tranquil lake witnessing native birds and wildlife, watching boats come and go or seeing (and hearing) the pounding waves of the Atlantic Ocean.
Here are the best places to enjoy those views:
Royal Palm Beach
Asador Patagonia Restaurant and Tiki Bar
The water view: Lake Royal Palm
This premiere Argentinian steakhouse and tiki bar is located at the corner of Southern and Royal Palm Beach boulevards in the heart of Royal Palm Beach. They are focused on a creating unique experience with an emphasis on fantastic hospitality. Using the best USDA meats, their menu celebrates the traditional Argentine asado, or barbecue grilled meats. The tiki bar behind the restaurant offers a view of the serene lake and a wide selection of libations.
Details: 675 Royal Palm Beach Blvd., Royal Palm Beach. 561-651-9477; asadorpatagoniawpb.com
West Palm Beach restaurants
Lamarina
The water view: Intracoastal Waterway
Located within Safe Harbor Rybovich along Flagler Drive, Lamarina opened on Nov. 19, 2024. Through its menu, decor, service and ambiance, the restaurant is designed to transport guests to their favorite coastal destinations. The menu, curated by chefs Alex Bustamante and Kent Thurston, draws its inspiration from Mediterranean, Latin and Asian flavors, will definitely complete the final leg of the journey. Standout options include the Maine lobster spaghetti with spicy pomodoro and pangrattato; the butterflied branzino with preserved lemon and green goddess raita; the Châtel Farms prime New York strip 10-ounce with shallot butter and salsa verde; and the Sunbird Farms chicken milanese.
Details: 4050 N. Flagler Drive, West Palm Beach. lamarinawestpalm.com
Spruzzo
The water view: Intracoastal Waterway
Meaning "splash" in Italian, Spruzzo offers water views combined with rooftop ambiance. Enjoy golden-hour cocktails, Bossa Nova brunches and more. Curated by chef Daniel Pundik, the menu offers is inspired by coastal Mediterranean cuisine.
Details: 251 N. Narcissus Ave., West Palm Beach. spruzzowestpalm.com
Elisabetta's
The water view: Intracoastal Waterway
Situated along Flagler Drive just north of Clematis Street in West Palm Beach, Elisabetta's offers fantastic views of the Intracoastal Waterway, multimillion-dollar yachts and even the historic Whitehall in Palm Beach. They feature, seafood, steaks, pasta, pizza and an extensive wine list.
Details: 185 Banyan Blvd., West Palm Beach. 561-342-6699; elisabettas.com/wpb
Bar Capri
The water view: Intracoastal Waterway
This rooftop restaurant and bar features plenty of expertly-crafted libations along with an extensive pizza menu, salads and appetizers.
Details: 185 Banyan Blvd., West Palm Beach. barcapriwpb.com
E.R. Bradley’s Saloon
The water view: Intracoastal Waterway
This restaurant featuring covered open-air dining has been a favorite meeting spot for decades. A local landmark that made the move from Palm Beach approximately 30 years ago and recently celebrated their 40th anniversary, it has become an integral part of West Palm Beach's identity. Taking in the nautical motif, guests can relax with the breeze off the Intracoastal Waterway and live music several nights a week while enjoying ice-cold beverages and an extensive menu featuring salads, soups, sandwiches, tacos, burgers, large plates and more.
Details: 104 S. Clematis St., West Palm Beach. 561-833-3520; erbradleys.com
Lakeside Tiki Bar
The water view: Set overlooking Pine Lake.
Located at Hilton Palm Beach PBI, this waterfront restaurant is set on Pine Lake, which connects to Lake Clarke, Lake Osborne and reaches all the way down to Lake Ida. It features multiple boat slips to accommodate those arriving by watercraft.
Details: 150 Australian Ave., West Palm Beach. 561-684-9400; hilton.com
Darbster
The water view: C-51 canal off the Intracoastal Waterway
This vegan bistro put its name on the map by being one of the first restaurants prepared to cater to the family dog — and it’s actually named for the owner’s dog. Located just off of Dixie Highway on Arlington Road, it is situated on the C-51 canal that separates Lake Worth Beach from West Palm Beach. This cozy eatery has a few tables with a view of the canal. The food is fresh, flavorful and consistent, with innovative menu items and specials that capitalize on what’s in season.
Details: 8020 S. Dixie Highway, West Palm Beach. 561-586-2622; darbster.com
Palm Beach restaurants
Seafood Bar at The Breakers
The water view: Atlantic Ocean
The expansive ocean view combined with the upscale ambience make this a destination worthy of a Palm Beach must-do list. Take in the resplendent resort and enjoy "fresher-than-fresh" seafood for lunch or dinner and watch as chefs prepare it in their glamorous, exhibition-style kitchen.
Details: One S. County Road, Palm Beach. 877-724-3188; thebreakers.com
Al Fresco
The water view: Atlantic Ocean
The covered terrace at this Italian restaurant offers a wide view of the Atlantic Ocean, and early risers say breakfast is truly the best meal of the day here. Al Fresco serves breakfast a la carte, lunch and dinner daily. The menu features appetizers, pizzas, pasta dishes and entrées. Dine inside or out, but come hungry.
Details: 2345 S. Ocean Blvd. at the Par 3 Golf Course, Palm Beach. 561-273-4130; alfrescopb.com
Ambassador Grill Palm Beach
The water view: Intracoastal Waterway
Situated on the 8,000-square-foot pool deck of The Ambassador Palm Beach Hotel & Residence, this rooftop destination is open to the public and offers fantastic views of the Intracoastal Waterway and sunsets. The menu includes favorites like their Maine lobster roll, lobster risotto, steak frites, and more.
Details: 2730 S. Ocean Blvd., Palm Beach. ambassadorgrillpb.com
Seaway at the Four Seasons
The water view: Atlantic Ocean
Beneath a lush canopy of sea grapes, with the sounds of ocean waves soothing your soul, diners can relax with an icy-cold drink and meticulously prepared food. You don’t have to be a resort guest to enjoy a delectable meal with a view.
Details: 2800 S. Ocean Blvd., Palm Beach. 561-582-2800; fourseasons.com/palmbeach/dining/restaurants/seaway/
Brandon's at Tideline Ocean Resort & Spa
The water view: Atlantic Ocean
Brandon’s offers wide ocean views and a seasonal menu. To make the most of the azure water, grab a table on the oceanfront deck and enjoy the chef-driven breakfast, lunch and dinner delights along with a craft cocktail or two.
Details: 2842 S. Ocean Blvd., Palm Beach. 561-934-4040; tidelineresort.com
Acqua Café
The water view: Atlantic Ocean
The view may be limited, but this restaurant just across the Palm Beach town line is an overlooked treasure. Located in a commercial building wedged between the Tideline resort and Lake Worth Beach, its décor is South Beach-blue and silver. The bar is ultra-modern and the torch-lit screened patio is serene and relaxing. The cuisine is “modern, coastal Italian” with seafood, pasta and grilled meat and fish and a nice selection of wines.
Details: 2875 S. Ocean Blvd., Palm Beach. 561-547-0005; acquacafepb.com
Lake Worth Beach restaurants
The Beach Club on the Waterfront
The water view: Intracoastal Waterway
Located at the Lake Worth Beach Golf Course, this restaurant offers sandwiches and paninis, salads and fish tacos, pulled pork and buffalo chicken wraps and specializes in filling fare for hungry golfers and a serene setting to unwind after a game. The good news is you don’t have to golf to enjoy your visit. The patio overlooks a golf course water hazard with a view of the Intracoastal in the distance.
Details: 1 Seventh Ave. N., Lake Worth Beach. 561-582-9713; lakeworthbeachgolfclub.com/the-beach-club
Benny’s on the Beach
The water view: Atlantic Ocean
The popular dining destination now has two locations at Lake Worth Beach. Benny's on the Beach Pier and Benny's on the Beach Oceanwalk. Since in 1986, Benny's on the Beach Pier location has been serving locals and visitors. Pairing fresh seafood, burgers and sandwiches with mango margaritas and ice cold beer, this hot spot has even pulled in some A-list celebrities like chef Gordon Ramsay and rocker Jon Bon Jovi. Their Oceanwalk location is a mere 100 yards away and opened in late 2022.
Details: 10 S. Ocean Blvd., Lake Worth Beach. 561-582-9001; and Benny's on the Beach Oceanwalk location: 10 S Ocean Blvd Unit 7, Lake Worth Beach bennysonthebeach.com
Lantana restaurants
Dune Deck Café
The water view: Atlantic Ocean
This long-lasting local favorite for waterfront dining overlooks the public beach in Lantana. A super-casual restaurant with an unmatched view serves breakfast, lunch and brunch amid ocean breezes and swaying palms. The Sand Bar, located within the Dune Deck, is a great place for beverages while watching the waves
Details: 100 N. Ocean Blvd., Lantana. 561-582-0472; dunedeckcafe.com
Kona Bay Café
The water view: Sportsman's Park Marina
Sportsman's Park Marina (est. 1962) has an old Florida feel, and Kona Bay Café is a little like stepping back into that past. They offer Hawaiian-themed breakfast items like Kona coffee and coconut macadamia nut French toast and a great lunch menu with options like the mahi reuben, hula chicken and the lava burger.
Details: 310 E. Ocean Ave., Lantana. 561-429-3606; konabaycafe.com
Old Key Lime House
The water view: Sportsman's Park Marina
The Old Key Lime House restaurant is a fixture in Lantana with good reason. From its fresh-catch menu to its award-winning Key lime pie and sunset water views, the house delivers. The venue also hosts live music from local bands at the tiki bar.
Details: 300 E. Ocean Ave., Lantana. 561-582-1889; oldkeylimehouse.com
The Hive Waterfront Restaurant and Tiki Bar
The water view: Lake Osborne
This waterfront restaurant features a family-friendly dock, a full bar and plenty of covered outdoor seating. Situated on Lake Osborne and adjacent to John Prince Park, it is a beautiful respite with tons of birds and wildlife. The food is hearty bar food for hungry boaters, and Hive Hoagies are a specialty with daily lunch specials. The Hive hosts happy hour and music too.
Details: 2412 Floral Road, Lantana. 561-513-9168; facebook.com/thehive618
Manalapan restaurants
Breeze Ocean Kitchen at Eau Palm Beach
The water view: Atlantic Ocean
The sound of surf and sea is the backdrop for a fulfilling meal at Breeze. Take in this idyllic setting with good local craft beers, fine wine, refreshing cocktails and a menu featuring sharable plates, salads, tacos, sandwiches and fresh local catches.
Details: 100 S. Ocean Blvd., Manalapan. 561-533-6000; eaupalmbeach.com
Polpo at Eau Palm Beach
The water view: Atlantic Ocean
Italian for “octopus,” Polpo brings acclaimed restaurateur Ron Rosa’s seafood-focused menu from the Tri-State area to South Florida. Enjoy upscale fare inspired by regional dishes, an Italian-influenced wine selection, handcrafted cocktails, and classic aperitifs and digestives. Dine inside or outside, within sight of the ocean and terrace firepit.
Details: 100 S. Ocean Blvd., Manalapan. 561-540-4923; polpopalmbeach.com
Eddie Ritz is a journalist at The Palm Beach Post, part of the USA TODAY Florida Network. You can reach him at eritz@pbpost.com. Help support our journalism. Subscribe today.

Too Bad, So Sad: Lake Worth Beach’s August 5th Agenda Sells Out Public Interest
This Agenda Would be Gifting Millions in Public Land, Some Waterfront, to Developers and Wealthy Property Owners — Bulldozing History to Appease the Rich. If You Object? "Too bad, so sad."
By: Tyler W. Chapman
🧱 Downtown Alleys Given Away: Carving Up Public Space
New Business A (Resolution 42-2025)
The City is proposing to give away, “abandon”, two public alleys in the downtown core to accommodate the WMODA project’s design. These aren’t minor pathways — they’re part of the historic downtown grid that connects streets and provides access:
In the developer’s plans, one these alleys will be remade into a curated “Arts Alley” pedestrian walkway between the new museum and garage. The other alley running north to south will be absorbed into their private property. Note that maintenance and control will shift out of public hands for both. What was once a public right-of-way will become a privately managed space for a private development.
There’s bitter irony here: that north–south alley to be vacated is the very corridor that provides access to three historic cottages on the site – buildings that the WMODA project originally promised to help preserve. In early plans, the developer agreed to pay to help facilitate the relocation of these historically significant structures, but one of those buildings suffered a fire and was lost. The latest conversations from the City Commission indicate the remaining historic buildings will now be demolished. In short, the city is literally clearing the way — both legally and physically — for private construction that will erase pieces of our historic fabric.
🌊 Waterfront for the Few: Giving Away Public Land to the Rich
New Business G (Resolution 21-2025)
Full walk down this beautiful public greenspace (at 2x speed) Video from: Joe Capozzi
Perhaps the most brazen giveaway on the agenda: an approximately 350-foot-long by 40-foot-wide strip of public right-of-way on the Intracoastal waterfront — between 1302 and 1230 South Lakeside Drive — is poised to be given away, free of charge, to the wealthy homeowners on either side. This land is essentially a platted street end leading to the water, and it belongs to all of us. If this resolution passes, public access will vanish; the land will be absorbed into the millionaires’ manicured lawns, becoming their private property.
What does the public retain? Only a buried utility easement for pipes and wires under the ground. There will be no public pathway, no viewing area, nothing. A slice of waterfront, operating now as a small park and a kayak launch with a priceless view, will instead be fenced off for exclusive use by two property owners who already enjoy direct waterfrontage.
City staff, even though interim city manager Jamie Brown claims that staff has no spare time and is overburdend with tasks, reviewed this request (brought by a law firm on behalf of the homeowners who are listed on PAPA as Richard Gladstone to the South side and Thomas LaRose & Lorrie Wright LaRose on the North) and raised no major objections. Why does so much staff time, “Staff from Public Works, Water Utilities, Electric Utilities, Community Sustainability and City Legal Departments” go to helping give valuable land away to wealthy property owners with waterfront property? So, no talk of compensation to the taxpayers for the land value — it’s simply a gratis handover; free land given to wealthy property owners? The justification? According to the backup material, the justification for this giveaway is couched in terms of this being a necessity for the “health, safety, and welfare of the neighborhood” — as if a publicly owned alley is inherently a danger, and only by handing it to private interests can it be made safe (and profitable). Once it’s taken from the public, it’s gone forever.
🍽️ Benny’s Gets a Free Summer on the Beach on Your Dime
Unfinished Business C (Fifth Amendment to Lease with Benny’s on the Beach)
Lake Worth Beach’s generosity to insiders isn’t limited to developers — it extends to favored businesses, too. The latest example: Benny’s Ocean Walk, with one of the best locations in all of South Florida, is in line for a $57,000 rent holiday courtesy of the public. In this fifth lease amendment, the City is waiving two months of Benny’s rent as the restaurant undertakes renovations this fall. That covers the post-Labor Day closure through late October — amounting to $57,000 in rent the city won’t collect.
City leaders are spinning it as a fair trade for “capital improvements” Benny’s will make to the city-owned building, but Jamie Brown, interim city manager, made it clear that by the lease agreement the tenent, Benny’s Ocean Walk, would be required to pay for such improvements if they wanted them, so they’re looking to change the agreement.
Local businesses are crying foul at the special treatment. “It’s a poor business decision for the city to waive the rent… If I have to close my business, the city is not going to pay my rent,” said John Gatti, a nearby business owner according to wptv.com. In other words, why should one favored tenant get a free ride that no one else would?
This “free summer” comes on top of an already sweetheart deal. Benny’s has a long history of paying below-market rent for its prime oceanfront spot. Only as recently as 2023, after public uproar, did the Commission push the restaurant into a new lease with a series of stepped rent increases that moved it closer to market rate. Even with those hikes, Vice Mayor (at the time) McVoy noted the rates are still lower than what similar oceanfront eateries pay. And by the way — Benny’s parent company? It conveniently donated $5,000 to a political committee backing the commissioners who consistently bend over backwards to accommodate the restaurant. Coincidence? Maybe. But the optics are clear: it pays to have friends at City Hall.
🚨 WMODA: Millions in Public Subsidies, 8 Token Units
Public Hearing D (Ordinance 2025-06 – WMODA Mixed-Use Development)
At the heart of this agenda is the WMODA project — a luxury museum-apartment complex that blends private profit with public subsidy. The proposal calls for a massive giveaway in exchange for mere scraps:
Free public land: 1.7 acres downtown (valued by the city at about $3.3 million 10 years ago and most certainly worth far more now) to be “donated” to the developer.
Publicly-funded parking garage: up to 5-story, 270-space garage costing taxpayers $8.5 million — the developer gets the benefit, the city foots the bill.
Extra building rights: additional height and density via “Sustainable Bonus” and Transfer of Development Rights (essentially exceptions to zoning rules to maximize profits and lets the developer get away with not building the full 16 “affordable” units that would have been required under our LDRs).
And what does the public get in return? Just 8 “affordable” units in a 110-unit luxury tower. These units are designated as “workforce housing”. However, these units only need to be considered “affordable” for families making nearly $100k a year or households earning up to 120% of the Area Median Income of WPB, which has a significantly higher AMI than LWB. In other words, designed for people earning a moderate income, not people struggling to find affordable housing. For context, that threshold is well above what many working-class families here actually earn.
📏 Upzoning Downtown: Bulldozing for Bonus Profits
Public Hearings B & C (Ordinances 2025-05 and 2025-07)
City Hall isn’t just dishing out deals on specific projects — it’s rewriting the rulebook to favor more intensive development downtown. On the agenda are two zoning map changes that together upzone 16 parcels in the city’s core to the highest-density category, “Downtown (DT)”:
Five parcels in a city-initiated rezoning (second reading of Ordinance 2025-05) – these are north of 1st Ave South between S. J and S. K Streets.
Eleven parcels in a privately initiated rezoning (first reading of Ordinance 2025-07) — scattered along South L and M Streets just south of Lake Ave (the very area targeted by the WMODA development).
The effect of these changes is to allow taller buildings and more units where previously such massive projects were not allowed. It’s a green light for higher-density and luxury development to sweep into blocks that were once human-scaled. And buried in the details is an ugly truth: by approving the WMODA rezoning, the city also says it’s ready to authorize the demolition of at least three historic structures on those parcels. Remember those historic cottages the developer said they would save? The plan was to relocate them off-site; in reality, one burned down, and the others are now poised to meet the wrecking ball since the majority of the commission says it’s not worth moving them. In favor of demolishing these historic structures, Commissioner Segrich brushed off residents’ concerns with a phrase now burned into public memory: “Too bad, so sad.”
Higher density in the urban core can be a worthy goal when it includes genuine affordable housing or public benefits. But here it’s being done primarily to enrich a single project for a wealthy New York developer. We’re watching the character of our downtown – including some of its oldest buildings — be sacrificed for a developer’s convenience and profit.
🗣️ Make Your Voice Heard
This avalanche of giveaways and upzoning will be decided at the August 5, 2025 City Commission meeting — 6:00 PM at City Hall (Tuesday evening). Public comment is open on all these items. If you care about any of them, now is the time to speak up.
Attend in person: City Hall Commission Chamber, 7 N. Dixie Highway, Lake Worth Beach and fill out a Blue Card (reference the agenda item by letter or ordinance number – e.g. “Public Hearing D” for the WMODA deal, “New Business G” for the waterfront land giveaway, etc.)
Submit Comments Online: Use the City’s online public comment portal (reference the agenda item by letter or ordinance number – e.g. “Public Hearing D” for the WMODA deal, “New Business G” for the waterfront land giveaway, etc.). Written comments can be submitted in advance if you can’t log in live.
These proposals aren’t final until the Commission votes. Your voice can still make a difference — or at least make them think twice. As Commissioner McVoy stated: “What’s the rush? We are being reckless.”
🚨 In Summary
Lake Worth Beach isn’t just selling to the highest bidder – it’s giving away the store. Public land, public money, public trust — all offered up like an unattended bodega with a sign that effectively says, “The rich can take what they please.”
If we don’t push back, this will be the new normal. More public land will vanish into private hands. More sweetheart deals will slip through without scrutiny. And the diverse, working-class fabric of this city will be steadily plowed under — alley by alley, acre by acre – replaced by upscale projects and private enclaves.
This city belongs to all of us, not just those with money and influence. It’s time to say so, loud and clear. Lake Worth Beach’s leaders need to remember their job is to serve the public interest — not to shrug off our concerns with “too bad, so sad.”
Too bad, so sad? We’ll see about that.

argos_summary: Residents of Lake Worth Beach protested against the Weiner Museum of Decorative Arts (WMODA), a $60 million mixed-use development project, citing concerns over the use of public funds and the project's impact on the community. Despite the protests, city officials approved the project master plan, which includes a museum, commercial space, and apartments, with significant public funding involved. Critics argue that the project prioritizes private interests over public needs, particularly regarding affordable housing and historical preservation.
